chunks.title: OSHA Soil Type A — Trenching
chunks.content: Type A soil is the most stable. Cohesive soils with unconfined compressive strength of 1.5 tons per square foot or greater. Includes stiff clay, hardpan, caliche. No fissuring, no previous disturbance, no water seepage. Required slope: 3/4:1 (0.75H per 1V). Thumb penetration test: thumb barely penetrates. Pocket penetrometer reads 1.5 tsf or more.

chunks.title: OSHA Soil Type B — Trenching
chunks.content: Type B soil has cohesive or granular properties with unconfined compressive strength between 0.5 and 1.5 tsf. Includes angular gravel, silty clay, previously disturbed Type A soil, fissured soils. Required slope: 1:1 (1H per 1V). Most common soil classification in urban trench work. Thumb penetration 0.25 to 1 inch.

chunks.title: OSHA Soil Type C — Trenching
chunks.content: Type C is the least stable soil classification. Cohesive soils with unconfined strength less than 0.5 tsf, granular soils like sand and gravel, submerged soil, soil subject to water infiltration, or layered systems sloping into excavation. Required slope: 1.5:1 (1.5H per 1V). Benching is NOT permitted in Type C. Thumb penetrates more than 1 inch.

chunks.title: OSHA Required Slope Angles by Soil Type
chunks.content: OSHA 29 CFR 1926 Appendix B slope requirements: Type A soil — 53 degrees, 3/4:1 H:V ratio, 0.75 ft horizontal setback per foot of depth. Type B soil — 45 degrees, 1:1 H:V ratio, 1.0 ft setback per foot. Type C soil — 34 degrees, 1.5:1 H:V ratio, 1.5 ft setback per foot. Stable rock — 90 degrees vertical is allowed.

chunks.title: Competent Person Requirements — OSHA Excavation
chunks.content: A competent person must be present during all excavation work per OSHA 29 CFR 1926.651. Daily checklist: classify soil before workers enter, locate utilities (811 called 3+ days prior), surface encumbrances removed, spoil placed 2 ft minimum from edge, protective system in place, access and egress within 25 LF, water accumulation evaluated, atmospheric testing if depth over 4 ft, adjacent structures evaluated, inspection after rain or freeze-thaw.

chunks.title: Trench Shield and Box Requirements — OSHA
chunks.content: Trench shields (boxes) are permitted in all soil types as an alternative to sloping or shoring. Requirements: must extend 18 inches above top of unstable soil or within 2 ft of surface in stable soil. Workers must exit the shield before repositioning. Must be designed by a PE or meet manufacturer tabulated data. Spoil minimum 2 ft from trench edge. Maximum 2 ft of unprotected trench in front of and behind the shield.

chunks.title: OSHA PPE Requirements — Construction
chunks.content: 29 CFR 1926 Subpart E personal protective equipment for construction. Hard hat required where head injury risk exists — Class E for electrical. Safety glasses for grinding, drilling, concrete work. High visibility vest Class 2 minimum near traffic, Class 3 on highway ROW. Steel-toe boots for heavy equipment and material handling. Hearing protection when noise exceeds 85 dBA TWA. Fall protection at 6 ft leading edges. Respiratory protection for silica dust — PEL 50 micrograms per cubic meter.

chunks.title: OSHA Silica Rule 1926.1153
chunks.content: OSHA silica standard effective 2017. Permissible Exposure Limit: 50 micrograms per cubic meter 8-hour TWA. Action level: 25 micrograms per cubic meter. Employers must have a written exposure control plan, limit worker exposure, and provide medical surveillance. Applies to grinding, cutting, or drilling concrete, stone, or mortar. N95 respirator minimum for silica exposure.

chunks.title: Confined Space Entry — Construction OSHA 1926.1200
chunks.content: Confined spaces in construction regulated under 29 CFR 1926.1200. A permit-required confined space has a hazardous atmosphere, engulfment risk, internal configuration hazard, or other serious safety risk. Atmospheric testing order: 1) oxygen content (must be 19.5-23.5%), 2) flammable gases below 10% LEL, 3) toxic contaminants below PEL. Common confined spaces in underground utility: manholes, valve vaults, wet wells, lift stations. Over 60% of confined space fatalities are rescuers — never enter to rescue without proper equipment.

chunks.title: 811 Blue Stakes — Call Before You Dig
chunks.content: 811 is the national call before you dig number. Blue Stakes of Utah administers the program in Utah. Utah Code 54-8a requires notification at least 3 business days (72 hours) before any excavation. The 5 steps: 1) Call or click 811, 2) Wait the full time, 3) Confirm all markings via EPR, 4) Respect and protect marks, 5) Hand dig within 24 inches of each mark (tolerance zone). Failure to notify can result in fines and full liability for damage.

chunks.title: Utility Marking Color Codes — APWA Standard
chunks.content: APWA uniform color code for underground utility markings. Red: electric power lines, cables, conduit, lighting. Orange: telecommunication, alarm, signal lines, cable TV, fiber optic. Yellow: gas, oil, steam, petroleum, gaseous materials. Green: sewers, storm drain, drain tile. Blue: potable water. Purple: reclaimed water, irrigation, non-potable. Pink: temporary survey markings, unknown utilities. White: proposed excavation area — mark your dig zone in white. Gray: temporary dewatering lines.

chunks.title: Trench Volume Calculator
chunks.content: Calculate excavation volume, backfill, bedding, and spoil for a trench. Inputs: trench length in linear feet, width in feet, depth in feet, pipe OD in inches, bedding thickness in inches, soil swell factor percentage, import backfill option. Outputs: excavation cubic yards, pipe void, bedding CY and tons, backfill required CY, spoil to haul CY with swell, spoil weight in tons. Swell factor: 25% typical for clay/silty soils, 10-15% for sand, 30-40% for rock.

chunks.title: Pipe Flow Calculator — Manning's Equation
chunks.content: Calculate gravity pipe flow capacity and velocity using Manning's equation Q equals (1/n) times A times R to the 2/3 power times S to the 1/2 power. Inputs: pipe diameter in inches, pipe slope in ft/ft, Manning's n coefficient, flow depth ratio d/D. Manning's n values: concrete RCP 0.013, PVC 0.012, HDPE 0.011, ductile iron 0.015, CMP 0.024. Outputs: flow in GPM and CFS, velocity in ft/s, flow area. Maximum hydraulic capacity occurs at about 93% full not 100%.

chunks.title: Minimum Pipe Slope Calculator
chunks.content: Calculate minimum slope required to achieve self-cleaning velocity in gravity sewer and storm drain. ASCE MOP 36 minimum: 2.0 ft/s at design flow. Recommended: 2.5 ft/s. Formula: slope equals (velocity times n divided by R to the 2/3) squared. Larger diameter pipe needs less slope. Inputs: pipe diameter, Manning's n, target velocity. Output: minimum slope in ft/ft and percent, drop per 100 LF in feet and inches.

chunks.title: Trench Safety Calculator — OSHA
chunks.content: Calculate OSHA required protective system dimensions based on soil type, trench depth, and protection method. Soil types A, B, C. Methods: sloping, benching, trench shield. Outputs slope ratio, horizontal setback each side, total top width. Benching not permitted in Type C soil. Any excavation over 5 feet requires a protective system. Over 20 feet requires PE designed system.

chunks.title: Thrust Block Sizing Calculator
chunks.content: Calculate thrust force and concrete bearing area for pipe fittings. Thrust formula: T equals 2 times P times A times sin of half the bend angle for bends. T equals P times A for dead ends and tees. Inputs: pipe diameter inches, test pressure PSI, fitting type (90 degree, 45 degree, 22.5 degree, tee, dead end), soil bearing capacity PSF. Outputs: thrust in pounds force, minimum bearing area SF, design area with safety factor, approximate square block dimensions, concrete volume in CY.

chunks.title: Grade and Slope Calculator
chunks.content: Convert between percent grade, ft/ft slope, degrees, and rise over run. Calculate elevation change over a distance. Calculate grade from two elevations. Outputs: grade percentage, ft/ft ratio, angle in degrees, drop or rise over specified distance, slope ratio H:V.

chunks.title: Compaction Calculator — Relative Compaction and Lifts
chunks.content: Calculate relative compaction from Proctor test data. Formula: relative compaction equals field dry density divided by max dry density times 100. Common requirements: 95% Standard Proctor for trench backfill standard, 90% for subgrade or fill, 98% for pavement subbase. Also calculate number of lifts needed: divide total fill depth by lift thickness per compactor type. Vibratory plate: 6-8 inch lifts. Jumping jack tamper: 4-8 inch lifts. Hand tamper: 3-6 inch lifts.

chunks.title: Markup and Bid Price Calculator
chunks.content: Calculate bid price from direct cost using separate overhead and profit. Formula: bid equals direct cost times (1 plus overhead) times (1 plus profit). Typical heavy civil overhead: 10-15%. Profit: 8-15% depending on risk. Also reverse: bid price to implied direct cost. Shows overhead dollar amount, profit dollar amount, total markup percentage on cost, and margin on bid.

chunks.title: Unit Price Builder Calculator
chunks.content: Build a unit bid price from material, labor, equipment, and subcontractor cost components. Applies overhead and profit markup to get the unit bid price. Multiplies by quantity for extended total. Units: LF, CY, EA, TON, SF, LS. Shows each cost component per unit and the final bid price per unit with extended total.

chunks.title: Change Order Calculator
chunks.content: Calculate change order value on time and materials or unit price basis. T&M inputs: labor hours and rates by trade, equipment hours and rates, material cost. Unit price inputs: description, quantity, unit, unit price. Applies overhead and profit percentage and bond rate. Outputs subtotal, O&P, bond, and total change order value.

chunks.title: Production Rate Calculator
chunks.content: Calculate project duration, cost per unit, and total direct cost from production rate. Typical production rates heavy civil: 8-inch waterline 150-300 LF per day. 8-inch sewer 100-200 LF per day. Trench excavation 300-600 LF per day. Backfill 400-800 LF per day. Inputs: production rate per day, total quantity, crew size, crew hourly rate, hours per day, equipment daily cost.

chunks.title: Crew Day Cost Calculator
chunks.content: Calculate total daily crew cost with dynamic add-remove labor and equipment rows. Inputs: role name, hours, hourly rate per worker, equipment daily rates, small tools allowance, overhead burden percentage. Outputs labor total by person, equipment total, subtotal, overhead, and total day cost. Useful for T&M pricing and daily report cost tracking.

chunks.title: Construction Unit Converter
chunks.content: Convert between construction units across 7 categories. Volume: CY, CF, CI, gallons, liters, cubic meters. Area: SF, SY, acres, square meters. Weight: pounds, short tons, metric tons, kilograms. Pressure: PSI, PSF, bar, kPa, ft of water, meters of water. Length: feet, inches, yards, miles, meters, millimeters. Flow: GPM, CFS, liters per second, MGD. Earthwork: BCY, LCY with 25/30/40% swell, CCY with 10/15/20% shrink.

chunks.title: Concrete Volume Calculator
chunks.content: Calculate concrete volume in cubic yards for slabs, walls, and cylinders or manholes. Slab: length times width times thickness divided by 27. Wall: length times height times thickness. Cylinder or manhole: pi divided by 4 times (OD squared minus ID squared) times height. Applies waste factor. Shows net CY, CY with waste, cost estimate by PSI strength, and number of truck loads.

chunks.title: Asphalt Tonnage Calculator
chunks.content: Calculate hot mix asphalt tonnage for pavement, patching, or trench restoration. HMA density approximately 145 lb per CF. Formula: area times thickness in feet times density divided by 2000 equals tons. Applies waste factor. Shows net tonnage, tonnage with waste, and material cost. Typical densities: dense graded HMA 140-150 lb/CF, SMA 148-152, open graded 110-120.

chunks.title: Pipe and Fittings Quantity Calculator
chunks.content: Calculate pipe, fittings, and bedding quantities for a pipeline. Inputs: pipe length LF, diameter inches, pipe material, joint length, number of 90-degree elbows, 45-degree elbows, tees, couplings. Also calculates bedding volume and crushed rock tonnage based on bedding depth and trench width. Materials: PVC C900, HDPE, DIP, PVC SDR 35, RCP, steel.

chunks.title: Manning's n Roughness Coefficient Values
chunks.content: Manning's n reference for common pipe and channel materials. Concrete pipe RCP: 0.011-0.013-0.015. PVC pipe: 0.010-0.012-0.013. HDPE smooth: 0.009-0.011-0.013. Ductile iron: 0.013-0.015-0.016. Steel welded: 0.012-0.014-0.017. Corrugated metal CMP: 0.020-0.024-0.030. Vitrified clay VCP: 0.011-0.013-0.015. Cast iron: 0.012-0.013-0.015. Concrete lined channel: 0.012-0.013-0.015. Earth channel clean: 0.020-0.025-0.030.

chunks.title: PVC C900 Pipe Specifications
chunks.content: PVC C900 pressure pipe for water distribution. AWWA C900 standard. Size range 4 to 60 inches. Push-on gasket joints. DR18 rating 165 PSI, DR14 rating 200 PSI. Common OD: 4-inch 4.500 in, 6-inch 6.625 in, 8-inch 8.625 in, 10-inch 10.750 in, 12-inch 12.750 in. Most common water distribution pipe material in the US.

chunks.title: HDPE Pipe Specifications
chunks.content: High density polyethylene pipe. ASTM D3035 standard. Fully restrained joints via butt fusion or electrofusion. DR11 rating 200 PSI, DR17 rating 100 PSI. Excellent for directional drill crossings, force mains, rough soil. OD: 4-inch 4.500 in (DR11 wall 0.409 in, DR17 wall 0.265 in), 6-inch 6.625 in, 8-inch 8.625 in. Sizes half inch through 63 inch. Flexible joint accommodates ground movement.

chunks.title: Ductile Iron Pipe Specifications
chunks.content: Ductile iron pipe for water and pressure sewer. AWWA C151 standard. Size range 3 to 64 inches. Push-on or mechanical joints. Pressure Class 350 standard. OD: 4-inch 4.800 in, 6-inch 6.900 in, 8-inch 9.050 in, 10-inch 11.100 in, 12-inch 13.200 in. Weight: 4-inch 13.35 lb/ft, 8-inch 27.75 lb/ft, 12-inch 47.03 lb/ft. Restrained joints required at fittings and on long runs.

chunks.title: Reinforced Concrete Pipe Specifications
chunks.content: Reinforced concrete pipe for storm drain and culverts. ASTM C76 standard. Class III most common. Gravity flow only. Size range 12 to 144 inches. Wall B construction. OD: 12-inch 14.0 in (weight 79 lb/ft), 18-inch 21.0 in (weight 174 lb/ft), 24-inch 27.0 in (weight 289 lb/ft), 36-inch 39.0 in (weight 563 lb/ft). Bell and spigot with O-ring gasket joint.

chunks.title: Soil Classification Reference — Swell Shrink Bearing
chunks.content: Soil engineering properties for construction. Sand clean: swell 10-15%, shrink 5-10%, bearing 1500-3000 PSF. Gravel: swell 10-20%, shrink 5-10%, bearing 3000-6000 PSF. Silty clay: swell 20-30%, shrink 10-15%, bearing 1000-2000 PSF. Stiff clay: swell 25-35%, shrink 15-20%, bearing 2000-4000 PSF. Soft clay: swell 30-40%, shrink 20-25%, bearing 500-1000 PSF. Rock soft: swell 25-40%, bearing 10000-50000 PSF. Rock hard: swell 30-50%, bearing 50000+ PSF.

chunks.title: What is an ESOP — Employee Stock Ownership Plan
chunks.content: An ESOP is a qualified retirement plan that holds company stock for employees. In construction, employees gradually become owners without paying out of pocket. Shares allocated annually based on compensation or tenure. Vesting typically 3-6 years. When employees leave or retire the ESOP buys back shares at fair market value. S-corp ESOPs may eliminate federal income tax on ESOP-owned profit. Common reasons contractors go ESOP: succession planning, recruiting retention, tax benefits, culture, protection from private equity acquisition.

ESOP employee owned: employees are owners through trust, strong retention, tax advantages, common in heavy civil. chunks.title: Python Hydraulics Tools — pipe_flow_full and minimum_slope
chunks.content: openmud Python tools for hydraulic calculations. pipe_flow_full(diameter_in, slope, n) calculates Manning's full pipe flow in CFS and GPM, velocity in ft/s, area, and hydraulic radius. pipe_flow_partial(diameter_in, slope, depth_ratio, n) calculates partial flow at any d/D ratio. minimum_slope(diameter_in, target_velocity, n) solves for minimum slope to achieve self-cleaning velocity. flow_to_slope(diameter_in, target_flow_gpm, n) finds required slope for a target flow. Available via: from tools.field.hydraulics import pipe_flow_full, minimum_slope.

chunks.title: AWWA Standards for Water Pipe
chunks.content: American Water Works Association standards for water distribution. AWWA C900: PVC pressure pipe 4-60 inch. AWWA C151: ductile iron pipe specifications. AWWA C200: steel water pipe. AWWA C104: cement mortar lining for DIP. AWWA C900 DR ratings: DR18 165 PSI, DR14 200 PSI, DR11 235 PSI. All pressure rated for water distribution service.

chunks.title: ASTM Standards for Sewer and Storm Pipe
chunks.content: ASTM standards for gravity sewer and storm drain pipe. ASTM D3034: PVC sewer pipe SDR 35 gravity flow 4-15 inch. ASTM D3035: HDPE pipe for pressure applications. ASTM C76: reinforced concrete pipe storm drain Class I through V. ASTM C700: vitrified clay pipe. ASTM F679: PVC large diameter gravity sewer 18 inch and larger. ASTM D2241: PVC pressure rated pipe SDR 17.

chunks.title: Construction Glossary — 811 to Confined Space
chunks.content: Key construction terms. 811: national call before you dig number. AASHTO: American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials. Angle of repose: steepest angle loose material stays stable. APWA: sets utility color codes. As-builts: drawings reflecting actual constructed conditions. AWWA: American Water Works Association sets water pipe standards. Backfill: material refilling trench after pipe install. BCY: bank cubic yards in-place soil volume. Bedding: granular material below and around pipe. Blue stakes: Utah 811 utility locating program. Bore: directional drill or jack-and-bore trenchless install. Butt fusion: HDPE joining method heating and pressing pipe ends.

chunks.title: Construction Glossary — CCY to Force Main
chunks.content: Key construction terms continued. CCY: compacted cubic yards after compaction, 10-20% less than BCY. Change order: written document modifying contract scope price or schedule. CIP: cast iron pipe older water distribution. CMP: corrugated metal pipe for culverts and storm drain. Competent person: OSHA defined person who identifies excavation hazards. Compaction: mechanical densification of soil. Confined space: limited entry not for continuous occupancy like manholes. D/B: design-build project delivery. Dewatering: removal of groundwater from excavation. DIP: ductile iron pipe for water and pressure sewer. DR: dimension ratio pipe OD divided by wall thickness. EPR: electronic positive response for 811 locate status. Force main: pressurized sewer pipe using pump pressure.

chunks.title: Construction Glossary — GVW to Work Zone
chunks.content: Key construction terms. GVW: gross vehicle weight. Haunching: bedding material at sides of pipe from bedding to springline. HDD: horizontal directional drilling trenchless pipe install. HDPE: high density polyethylene pipe flexible fusion joints. Invert: lowest interior point of pipe, invert elevations control flow. LCY: loose cubic yards after excavation with swell. LEL: lower explosive limit for confined space. Potholing: hand excavating to expose utilities before digging. Prevailing wage: minimum rates on public works projects. RFI: request for information asking engineer to clarify. ROW: right of way legal corridor for construction. Schedule of values: contract price breakdown by work item for pay apps. Spoil: excavated material minimum 2 ft from trench edge. Swell: volume increase of soil when excavated. T&M: time and materials basis for change orders. Tolerance zone: 24 inches each side of utility marks hand dig only.

chunks.title: openmud Mission and Platform Overview
chunks.content: openmud is an open source AI platform for heavy civil and underground utility construction. MIT license, completely free, no paywall. Mission: make AI a practical tool for every phase of the job from bid to closeout. The platform includes AI chat tuned for heavy civil, 18 construction calculators, OSHA and 811 safety reference, construction company directory, Python tool library for developers, open source GitHub repository at github.com/masonearl/openmud. Goal: automate the monotony of construction — bid generation, proposal documents, daily reports, takeoffs, email filtering, document extraction, RFI tracking, scheduling. Built by contractors for contractors.

chunks.content: The About page at openmud.ai/about explains openmud's mission: make AI a practical tool for every phase of construction, from bid to closeout. Built by contractors for contractors. Covers: AI chat, calculators, resources, companies directory, Python tools library, GitHub open source project. Also includes Contech API information for developers who want to build on top of openmud. Contact: hi@masonearl.com.

chunks.title: What openmud Is Building — Roadmap and Vision
chunks.content: openmud is building the AI layer for heavy civil construction. Current tools: AI chat tuned for construction, 24 calculators, OSHA and safety reference, company directory, Python tool library. What is coming next: real tool calling so AI actually runs Python calculators during chat, change order generator, RFI tracker, automated takeoff from plan sheets, invoice generator, daily report automation, better regional pricing data. The vision is a construction OS — one platform from bid day to project closeout, open source and free forever. Contribute on GitHub or reach out at hi@masonearl.com.

chunks.title: Who openmud Is Built For
chunks.content: openmud is built for people who do heavy civil and underground utility construction work: estimators who bid waterline sewer storm drain and highway projects, project managers running crews and tracking costs, superintendents and foremen in the field, field engineers doing takeoffs and layout, developers building construction software who need an AI backend, and contractors who are tired of generic AI that doesn't know what a Type B soil is. Free and open source. No enterprise contract. No paywall.

chunks.title: Minimum Slope for 8-Inch Sewer Pipe
chunks.content: For an 8-inch PVC sewer pipe (Manning's n = 0.011) the minimum slope to achieve 2.5 ft/s self-cleaning velocity is approximately 0.0022 ft/ft (0.22 percent, or 0.26 inches per foot). At 2.0 ft/s the minimum slope is about 0.0014 ft/ft (0.14 percent). These are calculated full-pipe values. Most agencies require 2.5 ft/s. Use the minimum slope calculator at openmud.ai/calculators for other diameters and n values.

chunks.title: Minimum Slope for 6-Inch Sewer Pipe
chunks.content: For a 6-inch PVC sewer pipe (Manning's n = 0.011) the minimum slope for 2.5 ft/s is approximately 0.0035 ft/ft (0.35 percent, about 0.42 inches per foot). Smaller diameter pipe needs more slope to achieve the same velocity. ASCE minimum is 2.0 ft/s, most agencies specify 2.5 ft/s. Verify with the minimum slope calculator at openmud.ai/calculators.

chunks.title: Minimum Slope for 12-Inch Sewer Pipe
chunks.content: For a 12-inch concrete sewer pipe (Manning's n = 0.013) the minimum slope for 2.5 ft/s is approximately 0.0019 ft/ft (0.19 percent). For PVC (n=0.012): approximately 0.0016 ft/ft. Larger diameter pipe needs less slope. Many agencies set 0.005 ft/ft minimum regardless of velocity for large diameter. Verify with the minimum slope calculator at openmud.ai/calculators.

chunks.title: Horizontal Directional Drilling — HDD Guide
chunks.content: HDD is a trenchless method for installing pipe, conduit, or cable under roads, rivers, and structures. Process: bore a pilot hole using a steerable drill head, enlarge with a reamer to the required diameter, pull the product pipe back through. Common uses: water and sewer under roads, fiber conduit, gas lines, utility crossings. Advantages: no surface disruption, ROW preservation, lower cost in some conditions. Key specs: entry angle typically 8-12 degrees, exit angle 4-8 degrees. HDPE pipe is the most common product pipe. Slurry control is critical — bentonite drilling fluid.

chunks.title: GPS Machine Control — Excavators and Dozers
chunks.content: GPS machine control uses 3D design models and GNSS positioning to guide excavators, dozers, and graders to grade automatically. Systems include Trimble, Leica, and Topcon retrofit kits and factory-installed Komatsu and Caterpillar integrated systems. Dozer grade control: blade automatically adjusts to hit design grade. Excavator guidance: bucket tip position shown on cab display relative to design surface. Benefits: reduced staking, fewer survey checks, higher production, less over-excavation. Accuracy: 1-2 cm horizontal, 1-3 cm vertical with base station. Machine control is standard on large UDOT and DOT projects.

chunks.title: Drones and UAV for Construction Surveying
chunks.content: Drones equipped with photogrammetry or LiDAR cameras can survey a project site in hours instead of days. Outputs: orthomosaic maps, point clouds, digital elevation models, cut/fill volume calculations. Common platforms: DJI Matrice 300 RTK with Zenmuse L1 LiDAR, senseFly eBee X for large areas. Software: DroneDeploy, Pix4D, DJI Terra, Bentley ContextCapture. Accuracy: RTK GPS drones can achieve 1-3 cm horizontal. Use cases: monthly volume tracking, stockpile measurement, before/after grading verification, progress photos, RFI documentation.

chunks.title: Pipe Bedding Classes — ASTM and APWA
chunks.content: Pipe bedding determines how load is distributed to the pipe. Class A: concrete cradle or concrete arch, highest load factor. Class B: granular material from trench bottom to 6 inches above pipe, most common for pressure pipe. Class C: lightly compacted backfill from native material. Class D: hand placed compacted native material, minimal support. ASTM C12 (concrete pipe) and APWA specifies bedding classes by soil and pipe type. For PVC and HDPE flexible pipe: Class B is standard, compaction to 85% or better in the pipe zone is critical for preventing deflection.

chunks.title: Prevailing Wage — Davis Bacon and State Requirements
chunks.content: Federal Davis-Bacon Act requires prevailing wage on all federal construction contracts over 2000 dollars. State equivalents: Utah state prevailing wage applies to state funded projects over certain thresholds. Prevailing wage rates set by DOL are published by county and work classification: operator, laborer, carpenter, ironworker, electrician. Certified payroll required weekly. Consequences for non-compliance: back wages, debarment from future projects. Most UDOT and municipal projects trigger prevailing wage. Check current rates at dol.gov/agencies/whd/davis-bacon.

chunks.title: Thrust Block for 45 Degree Bend — Example Calculation
chunks.content: Example: 8-inch waterline, 150 PSI test pressure, 45-degree bend, sandy clay soil bearing 2000 PSF. Pipe area = pi/4 x (8/12)^2 = 0.349 SF. Pressure in PSF = 150 x 144 = 21600 PSF. Thrust = 2 x 21600 x 0.349 x sin(22.5 degrees) = 2 x 21600 x 0.349 x 0.383 = 5769 lbs. Minimum bearing area = 5769 / 2000 = 2.88 SF. Design area with 1.5 safety factor = 4.32 SF. Square block approximately 2.1 x 2.1 feet, 18 inches thick. Use the thrust block calculator at openmud.ai/calculators for other fittings and pressures.

chunks.title: Change Order Best Practices — Documentation and Pricing
chunks.content: Key practices for construction change orders. Documentation: photograph before and during, note time and date, get T&M ticket signed daily by owner's rep. Pricing: always include overhead and profit on top of direct cost, include bond rate, include extended general conditions if project duration is affected. Markup: 15-20% O&P is standard on most public works, some owners specify 10% in the contract — read the GCs. Time extension: price separately from dollar value, submit concurrent delay notice. Never start work on a verbal only. Always respond within the contract notice period. Use the change order calculator at openmud.ai/calculators.

chunks.title: Open Source Tools for Heavy Civil and Underground Construction
chunks.content: Several free, open-source tools are directly useful for heavy civil and underground utility contractors. QGIS (qgis.org) is a full GIS platform — free alternative to ArcGIS — used for site mapping, right-of-way review, grading plans, and utility corridor analysis. Runs on Windows, Mac, and Linux with no license cost. EngineeringPaper.xyz is a browser-based engineering calculation tool at engineeringpaper.xyz — create, save, and share hydraulic and structural calculations. Good for field engineers who need to document slope checks or thrust block sizing. Calcpad (calcpad.eu) is free, open-source software for mathematical and engineering calculations with unit support — useful for estimators building custom calculation sheets. IfcBorehole is a Python CLI tool for creating borehole records from Excel or GIS data — relevant for geotechnical and underground utility work where borehole logs need to be standardized. sPrint is a Chrome extension for batch-printing PDFs from BIM360 and ACC platforms — useful for project managers pulling plan sets. All projects listed in the AEC Open Source Directory at github.com/opensource-construction/osc-directory under MIT license.

chunks.title: AutoCAD Civil 3D, Dynamo, and Camber — Open Source Automation
chunks.content: AutoCAD Civil 3D is Autodesk's industry-standard CAD platform for heavy civil design — roads, grading, utilities, and drainage. It is used by most DOTs, engineering firms, and larger contractors for design deliverables. Civil 3D uses the DWG file format. Dynamo is a visual programming environment built into Civil 3D (and Revit) that lets engineers automate repetitive tasks without writing code — corridor processing, sheet generation, alignment edits, label updates. Camber is a free, open-source Dynamo package specifically for Civil 3D at github.com/mzjensen/Camber. It extends Civil 3D with additional nodes for pipes, structures, corridors, alignments, and survey data — things Dynamo does not support natively. Useful for contractors and engineers who use Civil 3D and want to automate takeoffs, coordinate with subcontractors, or speed up plan production. MIT license. Requires Civil 3D subscription (Autodesk, not free). Alternative to Civil 3D for smaller firms: OpenRoads Designer (Bentley) or FreeCAD with the BIM workbench.

chunks.title: QGIS for Civil Construction — Free GIS for Contractors
chunks.content: QGIS is a free, open-source GIS (Geographic Information System) at qgis.org. It is the primary open-source alternative to Esri ArcGIS, which costs thousands per year. For heavy civil and underground utility contractors, QGIS is useful for: importing utility as-built data (shapefiles, KML, GeoJSON), overlaying survey data on aerial imagery, reviewing right-of-way and easement boundaries, analyzing corridor routes for pipeline or conduit, and creating site maps for bid packages. QGIS reads most GIS formats — Shapefile, GeoPackage, GeoJSON, KML, WMS, WFS. It imports CAD files (DXF/DWG) with the DXF import tool. State DOTs and municipalities often publish GIS data in these formats for free. QGIS can export to PDF for plan sheets. Runs on Windows, Mac, and Linux. Free with no seat limit — useful for an office with multiple estimators. The learning curve is moderate; the QGIS documentation is solid and YouTube has many tutorials.

chunks.title: Free Engineering Calculation Tools — EngineeringPaper.xyz and Calcpad
chunks.content: EngineeringPaper.xyz is a free, browser-based engineering calculation tool. No install required — runs in Chrome or Firefox. You can create calculation sheets with proper units (feet, inches, psi, gpm, etc.), save them to your account, and share links with PEs, inspectors, or owners. Useful for field engineers needing to document minimum slope checks, thrust block sizing, or Manning's flow calculations. Available at engineeringpaper.xyz, MIT license. Calcpad is free, open-source software for mathematical and engineering calculations at calcpad.eu. It supports custom units, symbolic math, and lets you build reusable calculation templates. Useful for estimators who want to build their own takeoff sheets or engineering formulas without Excel. Both tools are good alternatives to paid software like Mathcad or hand-calc sheets. For trench-specific calculations, openmud's built-in calculators at openmud.ai/calculators handle trench volume, pipe flow, minimum slope, thrust block sizing, compaction, and more — no account required.

chunks.title: OpenStreetMap — Free Map Data for Construction
chunks.content: OpenStreetMap (openstreetmap.org) is a free, open-source map of the world built by volunteers. It is the open-source alternative to Google Maps — no API key required, no billing account, no per-request cost. For construction, OSM is useful for marking job site locations and coordinates, reviewing road access and corridor routing, overlaying utility as-built data, generating site coordinates for bluestakes and permit applications, and embedding interactive maps in web tools. OSM can be embedded in any browser page using Leaflet.js (MIT license). Tile URL: tile.openstreetmap.org. OSM data can be downloaded as shapefiles or GeoJSON and imported into QGIS for more advanced analysis. State DOTs and utilities publish their own GIS layers that can be overlaid on OSM. For heavy civil contractors, the most practical uses are: (1) marking a job site address and verifying access routes, (2) measuring corridor length for pipe installation bids, (3) generating GPS coordinates for bluestakes submissions, and (4) site logistics planning for staging, equipment access, and traffic control.

chunks.title: OCR and Document Extraction for Construction — PDF to Structured Data
chunks.content: OCR (optical character recognition) converts scanned documents and PDFs into machine-readable text. In construction, most documents arrive as PDFs: plan sheets, specifications, invoices, RFIs, change orders, submittals. OCR and document extraction lets AI read these documents and extract structured data. Key open-source tools: pdfplumber (Python, MIT) extracts text and tables from native PDFs — useful for typed invoices and digital specs. Tesseract is the leading open-source OCR engine — reads scanned images and handwritten-style text. pdf2image converts PDF pages to images before Tesseract processes them. OpenCV preprocesses images (deskew, denoise, contrast) before OCR for better accuracy. The typical pipeline is: upload PDF → extract text with pdfplumber → if no text layer, run Tesseract OCR → pass raw text to GPT-4o to extract structured fields (line items, quantities, amounts, dates, addresses) → output JSON. For construction: extract line items from subcontractor invoices, pull pipe sizes and stationing from plan sheets, read RFI numbers and response deadlines, extract quantities from pay applications. This data can feed downstream tools like change order generators, invoice reconcilers, and proposal builders.

chunks.title: Agentic AI for Construction — Automated Workflows and Task Execution
chunks.content: Agentic AI goes beyond answering questions — it executes tasks. In construction, this means AI that reads an invoice and flags discrepancies, pre-fills a bluestakes ticket from job address and scope, drafts an RFI response from project context, generates a change order from a field note, or processes an incoming email and routes it to the right action. openmud is building a tool library that AI agents can call during a conversation. When a user describes a task, the AI selects the right tool (proposal generator, bluestakes builder, schedule creator, OCR extractor), runs it, and returns a completed result. Two modes: user-triggered (user asks, agent executes) and event-triggered (a new document arrives, agent processes it automatically). The tool registry is in tools/registry.py using OpenAI function-calling schema. High-priority tools being built: bluestakes automation, email drafting agent, OCR document pipeline, change order generator, production tracker, and job site mapper using OpenStreetMap. All tools are free and open source under MIT license.

chunks.title: Design and CAD Software — Heavy Civil and Underground Utility
chunks.content: AutoCAD Civil 3D (Autodesk) is the industry-standard design platform for heavy civil — roads, grading, underground utilities, drainage, and corridors. Used by DOTs, engineering firms, and large contractors. Outputs DWG files, plan and profile sheets, and quantity reports. Subscription-based. Bluebeam Revu is the de facto standard for PDF markup and collaboration — estimators use it for digital takeoffs, PMs use it for RFI markups and submittals. Most plan sets are marked up in Bluebeam. OpenRoads Designer (Bentley Systems) is the Civil 3D equivalent for transportation and DOT work in states that use Bentley standards — uses DGN format. Carlson Software runs inside AutoCAD and is common for smaller contractors and surveyors doing site grading and utility work at a lower price point. Agisoft Metashape processes drone imagery into 3D models and orthomosaics for earthwork calculations, stockpile measurement, and site progress documentation.

chunks.title: Estimating and Takeoff Software — Heavy Civil
chunks.content: HCSS HeavyBid is the dominant estimating platform for heavy civil and highway construction — handles bid items, crew pricing, equipment rates, subcontractor bids, and bid schedule assembly. Integrates with HeavyJob for budget-to-actual tracking. Industry standard for DOT and municipal work. Stack CT is a cloud-based takeoff and estimating platform with a strong digital plan takeoff workflow — measure linear footage, area, and item counts on uploaded PDFs. More accessible price point than HCSS. B2W Software is an integrated platform for heavy civil estimating, scheduling, and field tracking that competes with HCSS. Bid2Win is an estimating platform strong in highway, pipeline, and utility work. PlanSwift is desktop takeoff software that exports to Excel — popular with smaller contractors. Construction Takeoff is a Mac-native app for PDF measurement and markup with no subscription required.

chunks.title: Field and Project Management Software — Heavy Civil
chunks.content: HCSS HeavyJob is the benchmark field management platform for heavy civil — foremen enter daily production quantities, labor hours, and equipment hours from the field. Office sees real-time cost vs. budget by bid item. Integrates with HeavyBid. Procore is the dominant cloud-based construction management platform for RFIs, submittals, drawings, and daily logs — most large GCs and owners now use it. Trimble Viewpoint (Vista/Spectrum) is an ERP system for construction covering accounting, payroll, equipment, and project management. Fieldwire is a mobile field management tool good for plan management, punch lists, and task assignment — works offline. Samsara is a fleet and equipment telematics platform for GPS tracking, engine hours, fuel, driver behavior, and ELD compliance. Tenna is construction-specific equipment tracking using GPS, Bluetooth, and cellular — tracks heavy iron down to small tools.

chunks.title: Safety Training Software — Construction
chunks.content: Tyfoom is a video-based micro-training platform built for construction crews. Short daily safety videos delivered to workers phones — watch, pass a quick quiz, completion is logged automatically. Available in multiple languages including Spanish. Covers OSHA topics, equipment safety, and trade-specific hazards. Used by large heavy civil contractors for OSHA documentation compliance. SafetyCulture (iAuditor) is a mobile inspection platform for custom safety checklists, JHA documentation, equipment pre-start inspections, and incident reporting with photo documentation. Predictive Solutions analyzes safety observation data to predict where incidents are likely to occur before they happen. HCSS Safety integrates with HeavyBid and HeavyJob for safety observations, near-miss reporting, and training documentation within the HCSS platform.

chunks.title: BuildWitt Training and Community — Heavy Civil
chunks.content: BuildWitt Training (buildwitt.com/training) is a video training platform built specifically for heavy civil and underground construction crews. Founded by Aaron Witt. Content covers machine operation, pipe installation, safety, leadership, and business — made on real job sites by people who actually do the work. Available in English and Spanish. One of the most practical training investments a heavy civil contractor can make. BuildWitt Community (buildwitt.com/community) is an online community for owners, operators, foremen, and estimators in dirt work and heavy civil. Active discussion on equipment, business, hiring, and operations. Aaron Witt and the BuildWitt team participate directly. BuildWitt YouTube channel (youtube.com/@BuildWitt) has free content on job site footage, equipment, and culture. NCCER (nccer.org) is the primary credentialing body for construction craft training in the US — certifications are portable and often required for public works projects. AGC (agc.org) is the primary trade association for general contractors — provides training, certification programs, industry data, and legislative advocacy. APWA (apwa.net) is the American Public Works Association — the people who own and maintain the infrastructure contractors build, and the publisher of the utility color-coding standard.
